p.seg: BIENNIAL REPORT of the Adjutant General of the State of Nebraska For 1921-1922

2 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL REPORT STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERALS DEPARTMENT LINCOLN' December 1, 1922. From | The Adjutant General of Nebraska. To: I His Excellency, Painuel R. McKelvie, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska Subject: Biennial Report of 1921 and 1922 1. In compliance with the requirements of Section 3305, Chapter 34, Article 1, Revised Statutes of Nebraska, 1922, the following biennial report for the calendar years 1921 and 1922 is respectfully submitted: LEGISLATION Liberal appropriation was made by the Legislature for the support of the National Guard and for the promotion of Rifle Practice, but the special session of the Legislature deducted $12,000 from our support fund, which is causing some handicap toward the end of the biennium in the perfection of new organizations which are required by the Federal Government. The appropriation for Armory Rental would have been inadequate had it not been determined that the organization of a 155 mm. Howitzer Regiment was not feasible in this State and that it would be utterly impossible to house the equipment furnished such an organization. At the urgent request of the officers and enlisted men of the National Guard, which was augmented by request from very many ex-service officers and enlisted men, a law was passed which takes the Adjutant General's Office out of politics and requires certain qualifications to make him eligible for appointment (see Sections 3305 and 3320, Chap - ter 34, Article 1, Revised Statutes, Nebraska, 1922. PROPERTY The National Guard of this State is now fully equipped with the latest and best Quartermaster, Ordnance, Medical and Signal property and are so equipped that they can take the field at any time of the year without hardship or suffering.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 3 HOUSE ROM, NO. 537, 1919-1 92O Conforming to House Roll 537, 1919-1920, Certificates of Service have been made and mailed to all ex-service men, serving from Ne - braska, whose records have been furnished this office by the War Department. Up to this time approximately ninety percent of the records of enlisted men have been furnished. Very few records for officers and no records for nurses have so far been furnished by the War Department. IUKLK RANGE The Rifle Range at Ashland, Nebraska, is not in condition to use as such at this time. It was the intention of the State to reconstruct this range at the State's expense in order that the annual encampments could bo held within the State. Application has been made to the War Department for funds to construct cement butts, cement target house and for placing the firing points in condition for use, and a survey has been made by a Regular Army Officer, also estimate sub - mitted for the construction of same and we are just in receipt of a letter promising that these funds will be made available by the War Department within a few days now, which will cause a great saving to the State and permit us to hold our annual camps of instruction within the State in the future, which will keep our Federal expendi - tures all at home. REORGANIZATION OF THE NATIONAL GUARD Since the last biennial report was submitted the organization of the 134th Infantry Regiment, Nebraska National Guard, has been com - pleted and Hospital Company No. 130, motorized, has been organized and equipped. Nebraska's allotment for the year ending July 1, 1923, is one Medical Regiment and one Quartermaster Train. The Quartermaster Train will be equipped and trained as Infantry and will therefore be of special value to the State in case additional Infantry troops are needed within its own borders. ANN1AL ENCAMPMENTS Under the requirements of the War Department it is now necessary to devote fifty percent of the time provided for annual training in target practice and it is therefore necessary to hold the annual field training some place where a target range of sufficient size is available for this purpose. August 17 to 31 inclusive, 1921, the Nebraska troops were trans - ported to Camp Dodge, Iowa. Owing to the fact that this was the

4 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL first mobilization for the Nebraska National Guard since the World War it was necessary to devote most of the time, when not on the Rifle Range, at target practice in close order work. The morale, spirit and discipline of the troops was excellent and at the end of the fifteen day period a very pronounced advancement had been made as could be seen by the most inexperienced observer. August 14 to 28 inclusive, 1922, arrangements w?re made to hold the annual field training at Plattsmouth, Nebraska, and the Federal Rifle Range was put in shape and made available for the use of the National Guard. The only land available for camp purposes is just east of the City of Plattsmouth and is on low ground which had formerly been the river bed. The soil is of a gumbo nature and a light rain would therefore cause cessation of work for several hours. The Rifle Range is inadequate for a large body of m?n and the results obtained at this camp were therefore not entirely satisfactory, though much progress was made taking the weather and conditions of the grounds into consideration. When not on the Rifle Range, the men were drilled in close and extended order work with the spirit and morale, if anything, a trifle better than the year previous. The In - fantry Regiment has advanced rapidly in the last two years and Hos - pital Company No. 130 was able to erect their Field Hospital at Plattsmouth. thereby giving much organization and amply providin troops in need of same. valuable instruction to this medical ; hospital facilities for any of the Lt. Col. W. A. McDaniel, D. O. the National Guard of Nebraska, troops in the field at both of the L., Senior Instructor, on duty with rendered valuable assistance to the above mentioned camps, as did the corps of Regular Army Officers assigned to us for instructional pur - poses. C. S. ARMY OFFICERS DESTAII.ED TO THE STATE W. A. McDaniel, Lt. Col. Inf., D. O. L., Senior Instructor, and John W. Crissy, Captain, Inf., D. O. L., Instructor, are assigned to the State of Nebraska for instructional purposes by th? War Department. Both of these officers are of great value to this office and render most valuable assistance to the Military Department of the State. DISORDERS WITHIX THE STATE On the evening of January 27, 1922, this office was informed by the Governor that he was called upon for troops to suppress lawless - ness and put down disorder^ in Nebraska City, Nebraska, and territory adjacent thereto and that he was of the opinion at that time that it would be necessary to send troops in, possibly the next day. About nine o'clock A. M. January 28, 1922, this office was informed by the

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 5 Governor that conditions in Nebraska City were such that immediate Military occupation would be necessary. General Orders No. 4, State of Nebraska, 1922, were immediately issued by the Governor and wired and phoned to the organizations effected, with the result that by 1:30 P. M., Co. A. of Auburn and Co. B, of Falls City, had arrived at Nebraska City and taken charge and by 5:30 P. M. complete Military occupation was perfected. All organizations and detachments s^nt to Nebraska City on this tour of duty conducted themselves in a dignified, soldierly manner and proved to be well disciplined and well trained troops and while con - ditions at Nebraska City were found to be really much worse than expected, the occupation was completed without the firing of a gun. A Military Commission was established and all violations of Military proclamations were tried thereunder. Appeals from the findings of the Military Commission were made to the United States District Court and decisions rendered thereby in favor of the State (findings of the Court attached hereto and made a part of this report). It K( X »l MKNDATIONS Owing to the fact that the National Guard is now paid, subsisted, equipped and transported by the Federal Government and that it de - volves upon the State to furnish armories for the respective organiza - tions and armory rentals are high all over the State, it is recommended that the State build its own armories and perfect a great saving thereby. CONCLUSION 1 wish to express my appreciation to your Excellency for the moral support, advice and for the uniform courtesy always extended by you to this Department. The Officers and men of the Nebraska National Guard have given me faithful and loyal support, without which no one can fill such an office as this with satisfaction to himself and credit to the State. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska.

6 REPORT OP THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN January 6, 1921. General Orders, No. 1. 1. Brigadier General Herbert adier General, Chief of Staff, The this date, January 6, 1921. J. Paul is hereby re-appointed Brig- Adjutant General, Nebraska, effective r 2. Major Harry C. Stein, Assistant Adjutant General, Nebraska, is hereby re-appointed Assistant Adjutant General, Nebraska, effective this date, January 6, 1921. SAMUEL R. McKELVIE, Governor. OFFICIAL: STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN January 26, 1921. General Orders, No. 2 The following Correspondence Course, to commence February 1, 1921, arranged by Lt. Col. W. A. McDaniel, Infantry, Inspector- Instructor for Nebraska, is prescribed for all Infantry and Staff Officers of the Nebraska National Guard. The subjects to be taken up by each officer as soon as he obtains the necessary text books. Certificates of proficiency will be given for all subjects completed and in which examinations are successfully passed. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General Nebraska. OFFICERS' CORRESPONDENCE SCHOOL FOR 1921 1. In compliance with Par. 504 N. G. Regulations, 1919, and Memorandum, Hq. 7th Corps Area, dated January 6, 1921, the follow - ing course of study is prescribed in the order named for all Infantry and Staff officers having available text books: (a) National Guard Regulations and Small Arms Firing Manual,

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 7 to the extent covered by questions in W. D. Doc. 974, examinations to be held after March 31, 1921, in these two subjects. (b) Field Service Regulations, Manual of Interior Guard Duty, Military Hygiene, First Aid Rules, Military Discipline and Courtesy and Topography, using the text books and to the extent covered by questions in W. D. Doc. 974, examination in these subjects to be given two weeks before the beginning of the 15 days field training for 1921. (c) The subjects for the remainder of 1921 will be prescribed at the time of or immediately after the 1921 encampment. (d) Without further instructions, each officer will begin the study of the prescril»ed course as soon as text books are available and examination questions will be mailed to them at the proper time. The use of text books for giving the answers will not be allowed and officers will be required to certify on honor that they were not so used. W. A. McDANIEL. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN January 29, 1921. General Orders No. 3. The following First Year training plan, prepared by the Senior In - structor-Instructor, N. N. G. is prescribed for all National Guard In - fantry units of this State and will be followed during the year 1921. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. TRAINING —FIRST YEAR 1. (a) Pursuant to the schedule, suggested as a guide by the Militia Bureau of the War Department, the following scheme of in - struction and division of time is prescribed for the first year's Armory training. General Order No. 5, dated Dec. 3, 1920, is not rescinded, but on the contrary, will be continued as a supplemental training pamphlet subsequent to the completion of six months' service and for all units of other Arms, as far as applicable, in addition to all Infantry units. The word "Near" before "Pack" In (f) page 6, G. O. No. 5, should be changed to "Neat" and "Locomation" in the second line of (g) page 6, should be changed to "Locomotion." (b) The program for fifteen days field training and four days

8 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL instruction for those especially selected, will be published after the dates for the encampment have been determined and before May 1, 1921. (c) Th subjects of instruction for each drill is not prescribed but instead the attention of all unit commanders is invited to Par. 483, N. G. Regulations, to Provisional Infantry Training Manual 1919 (W. D. Doc. 844 1 and to the advisability of laying plans for progres - sive advancement, having in view the training before encampment in those subjects to be carried out in camp. Such as range practice with rifle, automatic rifle, pistol and machine gun (including care and safety precautions in their use); tent pitching; ceremonies; minor tactics, both day and night (including use of patrols, messengers, scouts, advance guards, rear guards, attacks, retreats, outposts, convoys, etc.); and use of special weapons (machine gun, automatic rifle, bayonet hand grenade, rifle grenade, pistol, 37 mm. gun and light trench mortar). (d) The schedule allows but 72 hours armory training for a year, which is wholly inadequate. More time should be secured by having the five drills each month for which all can draw pay and by drilling more than the minimum one and one-half hours at each assembly. (e) Beginning with Feb. 1, 1921, each unit commander will submit to the State Adjutant General at the beginning of each month a drill program, showing in detail the proposed instruction for each drill assembly for that month. A copy of the proposed program for tke month will be posted conspicuously on the Company bulletin board at the beginning of the month. Names of instructors and substitutes in each subject must also be published in advance to allow them to prepare. When the month is completed, report will be made in a separate paragraph on the new proposed program whether the previous proposed program has been fully carried out, and if not, why not. RIFLE COMPANY SCHEDULE f) Subject Hours Recruit Instruction, (See Par. 40, I. D. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 9 Company, close order and combat _ _ 6 Ceremonies (I. D. R. and Guard Manual) _ 2 Musketry — including nomenclature, care and use of arms; safety precautions; preliminary drills, estimating distance and other observation practice; location, designation and division of targets and distribution of fire, etc 12 Automatic rifles, grenades, pistols, etc ■> Minor tactics, including patroling, scouting, signalling, trans - mission of verbal and written messages, out-post duty, ad - vance and rear guards, field fortification trenches, etc. (See Field Service Regulations) 7 Total 72 (g) Other reference books are as follows: Musketry, S. A. F. M. and W. D. Doc. 867. Topography, W. D. Doc. 695; Automatic pistol, W. D. Doc. 801; Machine guns, W. D. Docs. 615, 723 and 856; Hand grenades and rifle grenades. W. D. Doc. 823; 37 mm. gun, W. D. Doc 758; Automatic rifle. W. D. Docs. 845 and 853; Signalling, Signal Book 1916 and W. D. Doc. 830; Infantry Training, W. D. Doc. 844. MACHINE GUN COMPANY SCHEDULE (h) Same as for Rifle Companies except the difference in train - ing necessary for different arms, equipment and duties required. HOWITZER COMPANY SCHEDULE (i) Same as for Rifle Companies except the difference in training necessary for different arms, equipment and duties required. SERVICE COMPANY SCHEDULE (j) Master Sergeants in the preparation of property returns, cor - respondence, rations returns; in studies of Army Regulations, Field Service Regulations, Infantry equipment, price list of clothing and equipment (annual general order of War Department), Quartermaster manual and other books and papers, also blank forms pertaining strictly to their duties as supply sergeants. First Sergeants, mess sergeants, stable sergeants, cooks, saddlers, as prescribed respectively for the same positions for a headquarters company. (See Tables of Organization "A"). Corporals as prescribed for stable sergeants. Saddlers as prescribed for horseshoers in a headquarters company, (See Tables of Organizations, "A"). Wagoners in the study of Manual for Farriers, Horseshoers, Sad-

10 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL dlers and Wagoners or Teamsters; the care and treatment of animals ■ and nomenclature, care and preservation of harness and wagons, i- . _ .... ... All noncommissioned officers will be instructed in signaling. All members in making pack, camp sanitation, personal hygiene and use of the first aid packet; the nomenclature, care and preserva - tion of the rifle or pistol, depending upon the weapon with which they are armed. All members armed with the rifle in sighting position and aiming drills and target practice. Band section as auxiliary sanitary troops in addition to regular band practice. REG. AND BN. HQ. COMPANY SCHEDULE (k) General training same as for rifle companies but special training as required for specialists. NOTE: Those Companies that are required to be equipped with animals, should have an apparatus on which to practice saddling, bridling, harnessing and packing. 2. Ordinarily drills or lectures in one subject should not exceed thirty minutes. Rests and interruptions cannot be counted as part of the one and one-half hours required for each drill assembly. 3. Because of the impossibility of mastering all the elements of the military profession in the short time alloted for training, every officer and noncommissioner officer should be given an opportunity to special - ize on certain subjects for the purpose of becoming instructors. 4. Because of the frequent changes in personnel and the uncertainty of life in general, every instructor's and specialist's position should have an understudy for substitute, competent to take up those duties when desired. 5. Armory schools should be conducted for officers, noncommis - sioned officers and understudies in I. D. R., F. S. R., S. A. F. M., M. P. T. and Manual for N. O. O. and Pvts. of Infantry. 6. All members of the company should receive instruction in the use of all special arms and cooks and buglers should study their particular duties. 7. All company officers, noncommissioned officers and buglers must know the signals prescribed in Pars. 43-47 I. D. R. W. A. McDANIEL, Lt. Col., Infantry I-I.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 11 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN February 3, 1921 General Orders No. 4 1. The current season of small-arms practice is hereby designated to extend from April 1, 1921, to December 31, 1921. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN April 4, 1921. General Orders No. 5 1. Pursuant to the Military Code the following are designated The Military Board of the State of Nebraska: Brigadier General Herbert J. Paul, The Adjutant General. Colonel Amos Thomas, 1st Infantry. Major John A. Lawler, Judge Advocate General. SAMUEL R. McKELVIE, The Governor of the State of Nebraska. OFFICIAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN April 29, 1921. General Orders No. 6 1. The 5th Separate (Provisional) Company, Infantry, Nebraska National Guard is hereby converted into the Howitzer Company, 1st Nebraska Infantry, (Provisional) effective May 1, 1921, to conform to modified table issued by the Militia Bureau, W. D., in connection with Circular Letter No. 1, M. B., W. D. 1921. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL:

OFFICIxVL: STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 18, 1921 General Orders, No. 8 1. In recognition of Memorial Day, Monday, May 20, 1921, con - secrated to the brave soldiers who sacrificed their lives for the Amer - ican Republic, the National Flag will, in accordance with paragraph 449 of the Regulations for the United States Army, be displayed on all Armories and all Stations of the Nebraska National Guard at half staff from sunrise until noon on that day. To assist in the observance of the day by Veteran Organizations, Commanding Officers of organiza - tions not in the Federal Sen-ice, will place their respective commands at the disposal of local representatives of the Grand Army of the Republic on that day. 2. Company Commanders will make a report to The Adjutant

REPORT OP THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 13 General of participation in Memorial Day exercises by their organiza- Pursuant to Pars. 832-914 N. G. Regulations 1919, to Army Regula - tions and to Circular Letters of the Militia Bureau, the following in - structions for the care of public property and for other interior economy of organizations of the National Guard of this State are published for the information and guidance of all concerned. . 1. Individuals will be required to sign a receipt for every article of equipment, clothing, publication and other public property issued to them. (A convenient method is to have a large sheet of paper fastened on a board with columns ruled for the different articles, appearing at the top of the sheet. The names of individuals on the left of the sheet, their signatures being on the same lines on the right). 2. Shoes, clothing and equipment will be fitted to the men under the personal direction of the organziation commander. 3. Pistols, ammunition, overcoats, blankets, underwear, housewives, toilet articles, wire cutters, intrenching tools and similar articles will not be issued until needed for camp or active duty. Frequent count should be made of such articles and every possible precaution taken for their safekeeping by accountable and responsible officers. 4. Blankets, overcoats and woolen uniforms and other woolen articles when not in use must be packed in moth balls or other pre - parations to prevent destruction by moths. 5. All arm chests and packing boxes will be kept on hand at armories for emergencies for packing articles not in use and for ship - ping articles to and from camp. 6. Blankets will not be unpacked for the purpose of instruction in making the "Pack," as the shelter half, rain coats and other articles ean be utilized for that purpose. ions, giving strength present, also names of absentees with reason 'or such, absence. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska OFFICIAL: STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 3, 1921. General Orders, No. 9

14 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 7. Enlisted men will not take their arms apart except by permis - sion from a Commissioned Officer under the proper supervision and only in the manner prescribed in the descriptive pamphlet of arms issued by the Ordnance Department (W. D. Doc. No. 987). 8. In addition to having small arms locked in arm lockers, arm racks and well-secured storerooms, they, as well as other property liable to theft should be kept hidden from public view and difficult to find or remove. 9. If an article of U. S. Property be lost, damaged or destroyed by negligence or fault of an officer or enlisted man he shall be required to pay the value thereof or the cost of necessary repairs. 10. Reasonable care cannot be considered as having been exercised for the safety of property when it appears that the loss, damage, de - struction or theft thereof was due to carelessness, willful neglect or failure to evercise ordinary foresight. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL: STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 9, 1921. General Orders, No. 10 1. All Commanding Officers hereinafter designated will report at the Adjutant General's Office, Lincoln, Nebraska, June sixteenth, 1921, at ten o'clock A. M. for the purpose of assisting in the designation of Battalion and Company organizations; duties preliminary to the annual field training, Nebr. National Guard, August 17 to 31 inclusive, and such other schooling and matters deemed necessary: Colonel and Lt. Colonel Commanding Regiment. Battalion Commanders. Company Commanders of all Separate Companies. 2. In case it is impossible for the Commanding Officer of any company to report at the aforementioned time and place, the 1st Lieutenant will be designated by the Company Commander as his alternate. 3. Transportation will be furnished from home station to Lincoln, Nebraska, and return. 4. One day's pay will b eallowed each officer for this tour of duty.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 15 5. The Olive Drab uniform and campaign hat is prescribed for this occasion. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. 18 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 22, 1921. General Orders, No. 12 1. As model pay rolls for the period ending June 30, 1921, are being distributed by the Corps Area Finance Officer, unit commanders will not complete their rolls until these models are received. The old separate company designations will be used on the rolls (or this period. 2. Pay rolls to be started July 1, 1921, will bear the new unit designation prescribed in G. O. No. 11, Nebraska, dated June 22, 1921. 3. The following decisions concerning pay are published in ad - vance of the model pay rolls for the information and guidance of all concerned : (a) Date of qualification for enlisted men is the date of the dual oath, except that the date of Federal recognition is the date of qualifications for those belonging to the unit when it was Federally recognized. Date of qualification for officers is the date prescribed by the Militia Bureau in extending Federal recognition to the individual or the unit to which he belongs. (b) Remarks showing promotion or reduction must give order before the date unless the order number is followed by the notation "ad." Example, "Prom. Sgt. fr Corp. O. No. 9, Jan. 31, 1921" or "Prom. Sgt. fr Corp. Jan. 31, 1921, O. No. 9, sd." "Prom. Sgt. fr Corp., Jan. 31, 1921, O. No. 9," cannot be ac- cepted. (c) Each calendar month is considered separately; no credit is given for the fractional part of a drill (1% hrs. ) ; officers cannot draw pay for more than 5 drills in one month and enlisted men for more than 8; and no enlisted man will receive pay for any month in which he has attended less than 60 per centum of the drills prescribed for that month. (d) Each drill is considered separately for the pay of company officers; for pay qualification for any drill at least 50 per centum of the commissioned strength of the unit must attend; 60 per centum of the actual enrolled enlisted strength must attend, except that 60 per centum of the maintainance strength must attend when the enrolled strength is less than the maintainance strength (60 per centum of 65 being required for all lettered companies, Service Co., Regl. Hdqrs. Co., and all companies required to maintain 65% of required strength for those under 65 in tables of organization).

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 19 (e) The inclusive dates he has commanded the company will be shown in remarks on form 367 opposite the Captain's name. (f) Character of drill or assembly at the top of Form 367b should be indicated by "a", "b", "c", "d", etc., in the small space alloted for that purpose and a legent showing the kind of drill repre - sented by each letter placed on the back of the form. (g) The totals at the bottom of 367b should include both officers and enlisted men, but the officers must be deducted from the totals on the last sheet before computing the percentage of enlisted attendance. (h) It is not necessary to eliminate the name and start a new record on Form 367b at the time a promotion or reduction occurs but it is necessary at the termination of the period to give the com - plete record in column of remarks under the new entry at the back of the roll whereby correct payment may be made and the original entry crossed out with red ink and a notation made as to why it was eliminated. 4. For preparation of pay rolls see Pars. 934 to 943 inclusive, N. G. Regulations, 1919. 5. Attention is invited to Cir. Letter 75, M. B., 1920, for unit designations and rank of officers. Call. 12:00— Mess Call. (b) Reveille and breakfast to be one hour later on Sundays and Holidays and all duties, except those necessary, be suspended for the day. 2. In the program of instruction given below, the following condi - tions are contemplated: (a) That the first week will be devoted to the elements of close and extended order, ceremonies, physical drill, minor tactics, prelim - inary drills for target practice, guard duty and other fundamental duties of the soldier; and the last week, to all phases of target prac - tice and other training that can be conducted advantageously for men

D. Doc. 844 — Prov. Inf. Tr. Manual, 1918). (gi That marches in full equ must be very short and easy at first march. With these, as well as wit indoor occupations and sedentary li\ borne in mind. pment should start at once but lengthening on each succ-*ding h physical and other drills, the of many of the men must be (h) That there be one simp and battalion and by the regimen Commander under proper supervi maneuver by each company hts prescribed by the Camp c or. M) That the organized a on Saturday afternoon should ake the nature of field day sports and should be military in character

22 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL as well as athletic, in order to utilize all available time for instruction and demonstrate something which would otherwise be omitted: Ex - ample, relaying verbal messages, pitching wall and pyramidal tents, bandaging and rescuing a wounded comrade. A committee should be appointed at the beginning of the encampment to determine features of the contest and prizes should be given, if possible. (j) That company conferences of instructors be held from 7:00 to 7:30 A. M.; battalion conferences for officers and specialists from 11:15 to 11:45 A. M., and camp conferences for all officers at 7:00 P. M. (k) That the closely supervised group system be used in all ordinary company and battalion drills in order that rest periods and time divisions for different subjects may be controlled. (See Part 2, W. D. Doc. 844). (1) That the following basic military training be required for all individuals of noncombatant branches, as well as alll of combatant branches, and that the standard of proficiency expected be based upon the standard laid down in W. D. Doc. 844 (Provisional Infantry Train - ing Manual, 1918): 1. Knowledge of Articles of War, Army Aegulations and order pertaining to the enlisted men 2. Military Courtesy and Customs of the Service. 3. Uniform Regulations. 4. Exercises for physical development 5. Elementary hygiene, social hygiene, first aid and sanitation. 6. Care of quarters and camp. 7. The school of the soldier. 8. The school of the squad. 9. Care, making up and use of personal equipment 10. Guard Duty. 11. Individual Cooking. 12. Tent pitching and camp expedients 13. Marching and march discipline. 14. Morale. (m) That the period from 6:45 to 7:20 A. M. be used for in - struction in and the actual performances of, the work of policing and arranging quarters, camp, bedding, clothing, army equipment, etc., for any casual inspection that might be made at a later time in the day. (n) That the band receive a special instruction in litter bearing, hygiene and first aid work as well as marching, ceremonies and band instrument practice. (o) That the rotational group system of training is especially effective, when several forms of special training are to be conducted

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 23 for brief periods and a special instructor is available to conduct each. (p) That the "Cadence System" is of great value because of its effect upon attention, concentration, smartness and morale and because it develops th? ability to give commands by all. (q) That instruction in minor tactics, given at conferences, drills, inarches, tactical walks and terrain exercises, will include patrolling, security on the march, security at the hall, the attack, the defense, map reading, sketching, and other elementary elements of field service. (See pages 16 to 19 and page 30, W. D. Doc. 844). (r) That the rifle companies conduct automatic rifle firing along with their rifle firing on the range and that as many officers and men as practicable have practice in firing the automatic rifle. , (s) That special periods bo set aside for firing machine guns and guns of the Howitzer company. (t) That this program is based upon the instruction of rifle companies and when the subjects for different periods are found to be inapplicable for other units will be departed from and instruction as prescribed in appropriate War Department documents be substituted instead. Col. of Infantry, Instructor, N. N. G. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN September 17, 1921. General Orders No. 16 The attention of all concerned is called to the necessity for strict observance of the following regulations of the War Department per - taining to the National Guard: 1. Maintenance Strength, X. G. Units: Although Circular Letter 53 M. B., dated August 10, 1921, prescribed that the required per centum of drill attendance be based upon the actual enrollment strength, Cir - cular Letter 48, M. B., dated July 23, 1921, authorizes the Chief M. B. to withdraw Federal recognition from those organizations failing to acquire the minimum active strength within six months after Federal recognition. The minimum active strength required to be maintained is prescribed in Paragraph 1, Circular Letter 31, M. B., dated May 5, 1921, and a variation of but 10 per cent either way is permitted. 2. Physical Examination of Applicants by a Physician Required Before Enlistment: Paragraph 350 N. G. Regulations requires that before a man be enlisted in the National Guard he be sent to a medical examiner, who will make a careful and thorough examination and will state whether he is satisfied that the applicant is within the required age limits and conforms in every respect to the requirements for en - listment. If in the opinion of the medical examiner, the applicant is disqualified in any particular, he will be rejected by the recruiting officer. If doubt exists as to the applicant's age, he will be required

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 29 to furnish competent proof other than his own oath. Officers enlisting unfit or unqualified men willfully or carelessly are liable to trial by court martial (Pars. 339-340 N. G. Reps.). When a Medical Officer is not available for making the physical examination required before enlistment, any graduate of a Medical School may be secured, the state paying fifty cents for each applicant so examined when a proper voucher is presented. National Guard Regulations — Wearing of Uniform: Paragraph 54 7 prohibits the wearing of the uniforms issued to members of the National Guard except at drill or other official occasions and prohibits the wearing of mixed uniform and civilian dress. Uniforms must be habitually worn by all officers and enlisted men who attend Armory drill or other military formations for the purpose of receiving credit for Armory instruction 4. Actual Participation in Armory Instruction: Section (b), Para- graph 491 N. G. Regulations, permits but one officer, one non-commis- sioned officer and one private of a company or similar unit to be given credit for drill, at a diill period, for work other than participation in the drill or other instruction. Actual participation for not less than one and one-half hours, exclusive of rests and interruptions, is required ot all other members of the unit in order to be entitled to drill pay. Maximum Monthly Pay Drills: The (5) pay drills referred tc in the last two lines of Circular Letter 51, M. B., 1921, and the note at the bottom of the first pace of G. O. 15, Nebraska, 1921, apply to company officers and field officers. Captains and Lieutenants not be- longing to organizations are on a monthly pay basis and must attend not less than four ( i) drills or satisfactorily perform other equivalent duties each month to be entitled to the four-thirtieth of the monthly base pay of their grades as prescribed in the Regular Army. If the number att?nded during a calendar month is below four (4), they shall receive for each drill attended or equivalent duty performed, one-fourth of their monthly rate. Sec. (c). Par. 3, Cir. Letter 51, M. B., July 29, 1921 BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENEF XL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN October 6, 1921. General Orders No. 18 The attention of all concerned is called to the importance of the following: 1. Standards of Physical Kxnmination: Sp^ial Regulations No. 65, W. D., having been superseded by A. R. 40-105, for the examina - tion of applicants for entrance into the National Guard, the latter will be strictly observed. 2. Mobilization of the National Guard: Special Regulations No. 55, W. D., having been supers°ded by Cir. 3, If. B., W. D., dated Nov. 18, 1920, pending a revision of the former, it is desired that each individual officer have a copy of the latter and a copy be on file at thf> headquarters of each unit. Sufficient copies have been dis - tributed for this purpose, but if any officer is without a copy request should be made to this office for one. 3. Riot Duty: Carefully prepared lectures on riot duty should be given all units, based on Military Protection (W. D. Doc. 882) and a Treatise on Riot Duty by Col. Bellews. 4. Records: The condition of the records of most units were reported as unsatisfactory at the time of the encampment, especially as regards completeness and accuracy. Attention is invited to Par. 346 N. G. Regs, and Sec. 93 Act of June 4, 1920, in connection with the Annual Armory Federal Inspection, which occurs soon after the beginning of the new calendar year. 5. Courts-Martial System: Although the Manual for Courts- Martial. U. S. Army, 1921, should be studied for examination of of - ficers and for Courts-Martial procedure, etc., Sees. 102-108, Act of June 4, 1920. and Pars. 571-605, N. G. Re-;s. 1919, govern as to pun - ishment limitations for National Guard units, not in Federal Service, rather than the provisions of the Courts-Martial manual.

40 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 2 SCHOOLS (a) CORRESPONDENCE COURSE FOR ALL OFFICERS EXCEPT MEDICAL OFFICERS For the sake of uniformity of instruction, officers will take the correspondence course of the 7th Corps Area Training Center instead of that prescribed to be given by the Federal Instructor of the State, in Par. 2, G. O. 15, Neb., 1921. The following alternative course is prescribed, to be conducted by the State Instructor if there is a hitch in the functioning of the Training Center Course: Jan. 1 to Feb. 28, 1922: Riot Duty — Military Protection, W. D. Doc. 882 (Page 62, War Dept. Doc. No. 974). Mar. 1 to April 30, 1922: Guard Duty — M. I. G. D., W. D. Doc. 466 (see Page 50, W. D. Doc. 974). May 1 to June 30, 1922: Infantry Drill — I. D. R. and Waldron, (see W. D. Doc. 970). Oct. 1 to Oct. 31, 1922: Military Topography — Grieves' Military Sketching and Map Reading (see Page 82, W. D. Doc. 974). Nov. 1 to Dec. 31, 1922: Minor Tactics — (Page 229, Vol. 1, Wal - dron and I. D. R., to be studied in connection with map problems). (b) NON-COMMISSIONED OFFICERS' SCHOOL School for non-commissioned officers and specially selected pri - vates, first class, to be conducted in each unit at least twice per month (except for July, August and September) in the subjects found in the two volumes of Waldron's Platoon Training, (Manual for N. C. O.'s and Privates and other Service manuals to be used whenever necessary as supplementary text books when there are not sufficient of the former). The subjects will be given as a correspondence course, under the direction of the unit commander, if it is found impracticable to conduct armory sessions. In either case, certificates of proficiency should be given to individuals when they actually complete and really become proficient in the different subjects. In order to coordinate non-commissioned officers' school with the preparatory course for a Reserve Corps Commission (soon to be announced) the following allotment of subjects is prescribed: Jan. 1 to Feb. 28, 1922: Interior Guard Duty and Military Cus - toms (M. I. D. G., Waldron and Chapters 1 and 7, N. C. O.'s Manual). March 1 to March 31, 1922: Military Hygiene — Pars. 45 to 78 and 565 to 616, Field Service Pocket Book (W. D. Doc. 605).

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 41 April 1 to June 30, 1922: Drill Regulations (including practical demonstration in conducting the drill, explanation of movements be - fore executing them and correction of errors after execution). Oct. 1 to Dec. 31, 1922: Topography (including practice in con - struction of scales; making of road sketches and contoured positions, and In the reading and use of maps and sketches) — Grieves' Military Sketching and Map Reading. 3. The services of Instructors and Sergeant-Instructors should be used to the greatest extent possible. Although they have no authority for giving orders and commands in a disciplinary way, there are no objections to their giving drill commands as assistant to the National Guard Instructor, acting as guide at drill or as member of a group requiring team work, (such as signalling, patrolling, tent pitching, transmission of messages, etc.). . Their commands and demonstrations, however, should be considered as being given for the purpose of imparting the knack of the idea to those who are later to give the same commands or demonstrations. For this reason as many officers and non-commissioned officers as pos - sible should be present. In no case should the drill be turned over to the Federal Instructor while school for the National Guard In - structors is being conducted elsewhere. The work of the Instructor or Sergeant-Instructor is to exemplify and is not to be continued along any particular line (except to advise) after the ability to give the necessary commands or demonstrations has been mastered by the National Guard instructor. Skill in the giving of certain commands and demonstrations, can be obtained only by repeated practice; among those of that class are those for physical drill, close order drill, bayonet fighting, tent pitching and small arms firing. Service in the Regular Army is supposed to have Imparted that required skill. W. A. McDANIEL, Lt. Col., Inf., D. O. L. Instr., Inf., N. N. G. OFFICIAL: STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 20, 1922. General Orders, No. 5 1. Before a Board which convened at the Nebraska National Guard Armory, Omaha, Nebraska, December 12, 1921, pursuant to Par. 1, R. S. O. No. 18, Hq. 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, Decem - ber 5, 1921, and of which Major Clyde E. McCormick, 134th Infantry, was President and Captain David M. Marvin, 134th Infantry, was Recorder, was arraigned Sergeant John J. Murphy, Company L, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, to determine whether or not said Sergeant John J. Murphy, Company L, 134th Infantry, should be dis - charged prior to the expiration of his term of enlistment on account of habits or traits of character which served to render his retention in the service undesirable, same being brought under authority of Par. 365, N. G. R., 1919. 2. February 27, 1922, the above mentioned Board reconvened at the Nebraska National Guard Armory, Omaha, Nebraska, for further consideration and deliberations in the above mentioned hearing, and the following conclusions were arrived at: "While on duty at the Fair Grounds at Lincoln, Nebraska, in Sep - tember, 1921, he (a) Showed disrespect for his superior officers, (b) Failed in his duties as a soldier and a non-commissioned officer, (c) Acted in such a way as to bring discredit on the Mili- tary Forces of the United States and of the State of Nebraska, (d) By his attitude encouraged other younger soldiers to become disgruntled and dissatisfied with conditions

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 45 which were admittedly not pleasant, but under the cir - cumstances bearable and fully within the duty of sol - diers to function efficiently under. Therefore the Board recommends that Sergeant John J. Murphy, Company L, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, be given a discharge from the National Guard of the State of Nebraska as author - ized in sub-paragraph (c), of Par. 362, N. G. R., 1919, and recommends that the character given on said discharge be shown as "Poor." 3. The foregoing findings of the Board are hereby approved and it is ordered that Sergeant John J. Murphy, Company L, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, be given a discharge from the National Guard of the State of Nebraska as authorized in sub-par, (c). Par. 362, N. G. R., 1919, and that the character given on said discharge be shown as "Poor." BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL: STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 23, 1922 General Orders No. 6 1. In' recognition of Memorial Day, Tuesday, May 30, 1922, con - secrated to the brave soldiers who sacrificed their lives for the Amer - ican Republic, the National flag will, in accordance with paragraph 449 of the Regulations for the United States Army, be displayed on all Armories and all stations of the Nebraska National Guard at half staff from sunrise until noon on that day. To assist in the observance of the day by Veteran organizations, Commanding Officers of organiza - tions not in the Federal service will place their respective commands at the disposal of local representatives of the Grand Army of the Re - public on that day. 2. Company Commanders will make a report to the Adjutant General of participation in Memorial Day exercises by their organiza - tions, giving strength present, also names of absentees with reason for such absence. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska.

General Orders No. 10 The following program prepared in compliance with Par. 459, Na - tional Guard Regulations, by the Senior State Instructor is prescribed for the Camp of Instruction at Plattsmouth, Nebr., from Aug. 14, 1922, to Aug. 28, 1922, inclusive, (subject to change by the Camp Com - mander, when necessary because of weather conditions or other cir - cumstances). BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, GENERAL PRINCIPLES 1. Because of the paramount importance in the use of weapons as instruments of destruction, estimating distance, observation drills and other exercises connected with Musketry, the schedule is arranged to require Combatant troops to devote two-thirds of the required time to firing or other instruction on the target range. 2. Staff officers and enlisted men and specialists whose duties and instruction are not prescribed in this schedule, are to perform, as far as practicable, all the functions appropriate to their respective

48 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL grades and offices as would devolve upon them in a Camp for actual field service (See G. O. 21, A. G. O., Nebr., 1921; Training Cir. 1, Inf., N. B., 1921, and special W. D. Documents, for subjects in which special - ists should be instructed). 3. The Guard and other daily camp details are to be furnished by units not firing. The pit and other range details are to be furnished from the units firing. 4. That training to be emphasized in camp, which is most dif - ficult to carry out in armory drill. 5. All theories to be taught by practical demonstration and the students to actually put into effect what they have been taught. 6. Some subjects suitable for lectures at the evening conference are the following, in addition to a critique of that day's work and plans for the following day: Camp routine and regulations. Infantry training (including attached staff units) The soldier's "Pack" and equipment. Security and information. The Machine Gun and its characteristics. Marksmanship and musketry. Physical drill and bayonet drill. Discipline, courtesy, customs, common sense and discretion. Communication (signalling and Field Message Blank). Topography and sketching. Riot duty, guard duty and semi-military duty. Tornado, flood, fire or other emergency call. Field Engineering. Night Operations. "Cadence System" and "Block System" of drill. CAMP ROUTINE Forenoon Reveille: 5:45 — First call for Reveille. 5:55 — March (by band and assembled field music). 6:00 — Reveille and assembly. (By assembled Field Music) Roll Call and Report after assembly. 6:15 — Mess Call. 6:45 — Sick Call and Fatigue Call. (Half hour to be used policing quarters, camp, weapons, etc.)

O.'s and Surgeons and others. 7:20 — First Call for Drill and other activities. 7:30 — Assembly for Drill. 11:30 — Recall. 11:45 — First Sergeants Call. 12:00 — Mess Call. Afternoon 12:50 — First Call for drill. 1:00 — Assembly for drill. 4:30 — Recall and sick call. (4:00 to 4:30 — Cleaning of weapons and supervised policing.) 4:35 — First call for guard mount. 4:40 — Assembly for guard mount 4:45 — Inspection by C. O.'s, surgeons and others. 5:00 — Mess call. 5:30 — First call for parade and retreat. 5.40— Assembly for parade and retreat. (Bores of all weapons fired, of units not parading to be inspected and men held in quar - ters to clean any that have been neglected). 6:30 — School call. 9 : 00 — Tattoo. 10:45 — Call to quarters. 11:00 — Taps. Note: Reveille and breakfast to be an hour later on Sundays and Holidays and as many duties as possible to be suspended on these days. GOVERNOR'S DAY 1. In order to allow as many people as possible to visit the Camp on Governor's Day, Sunday, Aug. 27th, is tentativel ydesignated with the following program: (a) — 9:30 to 11:00 A. M. — Firing by troops on the target ranges, (b) 4:00 P. M. — Review of entire command. 2. Saturday, Aug. 26th, is tentatively designated as the alternative date if the 27th is impracticable, the program to be: (a) 1:30 to 3:00 P. M.— Firing by troops on the target ranges. (b) 4:00 P. M. — Review of entire command.

By direction of the Secretary of War, the following officers of the 1st Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, are detailed to take the special course of instruction for National Guard officers from October 31, 1921, to January 31, 1922, at Camp Benning, Ga. : Capt. Emmett S. Powell, 1600 White St., Beatrice, Nebr. 1st Lt. Paul J. Auxier, 324 No. 16th St., Omaha, Nebr. 2. Attention is invited to Pars. 467-470, N. G. R., 1919, for strict observance. Pay is not allowed for any period on sick or ordinary leave. 3. Expenses involved are chargeable against Procurement Author - ization M. B.-18, P2812-A-2, AE & T NG-E, which numbers should appear on all papers required in effecting reimbursement. Accounts of the officers will be settled by the Finance Officer at Camp Benning.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 105 4. Student officers will be housed in barracks. No accommodations will be available at the Post for student officers' families, and it is practically impossible to rent suitable places of abode in Columbus. This detail is made on condition that the officers do not take their families. 5. The officers named above will report to the Commandant of the Infantry school on October 31, 1921, and upon completion of the course, or when relieved by the Commandant, they will return to their proper stations. 6. The travel directed is necessary In the military service. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General. OFFICIAL: STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN October 3, 1922. Special Orders, No. 142 1. By direction of the Secretary of War, the following officers of the 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, are detailed to take the special course of instruction for National Guard officers from No - vember 1. 1922, to January 31. 1923, at Fort Benning. Ga.: Capt. Lawrence E. Jones. Hastings, Nebr. 1st Lt. Miami O. York, Mitchell, Nebraska. 2. Attention is invited to Pars. 499-502, N. G. R., 1922. for strict observance. Pay is not allowed for any period on sick or ordinary leave. 3. Accounts of the officers will be settled by the United Stai Property and Disbursing OHicer. Expenses involved are chargeable against Procurement Auihorizalion M. B.-36, P2890-A-3, AE&TNG-E, which numbers should appear on all papers required in effecting re - imbursements. 4. Officers will be allowed five cents per mile over the shortest usually traveled route. Pullman expenses in addition to mileage are unauthorized. No Government quarters are available for families of officers. Transportation for dependents and houseohld goods is not authorized. Officers are now entitled to pay of their rank while Pvt. 1st Cl. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 217 TOUR OF DUTY AT NEBRASKA CITY PROCLAMATION WHEREAS, It appears that a state of lawnessness and disorder is now prevalent in Nebraska City, Nebraska, and territory adjacent thereto ,and WHEREAS, It appears that such condition of lawlessness and dis - order has existed for sometime, and is now rapidly becoming more pronounced and is out of and beyond the control of the civil authori - ties of laid territory, and WHEREAS, The County Attorney and the Sheriff of Otoe County, Nebraska, and the Mayor of Nebraska City, Nebraska, have applied for assistance from the State of Nebraska, requesting that the National Guard of the State of Nebraska be dispatched to, and placed In control of said territory, for the restoration and maintenance of law and order, and the proper execution of the laws of the State of Nebraska in said territory, now in said state of lawlessness and disorder, now, THEREFORE, I, Samuel R. McKelvie, Governor of the State of Nebraska, by virtue of my office, and the powers vested in me by the Constitution and laws of the State of Nebraska, do hereby order, announce and declare all of the territory comprising and included in Four-Mile Precinct, in Otoe County, Nebraska, including the city of Nebraska City, and all of its subdivisions to be now subject to and under martial law, and order such portion of the National Guard of the State of Nebraska, as may be necessary for said purpose of re - storing and maintaining law and order and properly executing the laws of the State of Nebraska in said territory, as may be designated by the Adjutant General of Nebraska for suchc purpose dispatched to said territory; (A) All law abiding citizens are requested to assist in the restoration of order by strict observance of the laws, by con - tinuing in the quiet pursuit of their usual avocations and by refraining from participation in assemblages which are or are likely to become tumultuous or otherwise unlawful. Given under my hand and the Great Seal of the State of Nebraska, this twenty - eighth day of January, 1922. (Seal) (Signed) SAMUEL R. McKELVIE, BY THE GOVERNOR: (Signed) Darius M. Amsberry, Secretary of State.

218 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL PROCLAMATION HEADQUARTERS NEBRASKA NATIONAL GUARD Nebraska City, January 28, 1922. Four Mile Precinct, in Otoe county, Nebraska, including the city of Nebraska City and all of its subdivisions, having been declared by the Governor of the state of Nebraska to be in a state of insurrection and i< jellion, and the military forces of the state having been ordered bj '\e Governor and Commander-in-Chief to assume charge and restore oiv )r in said Four Mile Precinct and city of Nebraska City and all of it; subdivisions, the commanding officer of said military forces hereby 1> iclaims the following rules and regulations which will be In force u til further orders: }. All pool halls, whether run in connection with other business o/ .lot, and all soft drink parlors, with card table accommodations, will immediately close and remain closed until further orders. 2. All persons in the possession of arms, equipment and munitions of war are required to surrender the same on or before Sunday, Jan - uary 29, 1922, at six o'clock, P. M., to the commanding officer of the military forces, taking receipt for the same at the Court House. 3. All persons who have heretofore given aid to or otherwise sup - ported the lawlessness hitherto existing in the above named district who shall return to peaceful occupations, holding no communication of any kind with the. lawless person or persons, will no tbe disturbed. 4. All rights of property of whatever kind will be held inviolate and will not be disturbed, except as the exigencies of the public welfare may necessitate, by direct command of the commanding officer of the district. 5. All shops and places, except as heretofore provided, will be kept open as usual in times of peace, and all persons are enjoined to continue their customary peaceful occupation. 6. Excepting as herein provided or where the existence of martial law implies the contrary the usual laws of the community will be in force; crimes will be subject to proper authority; civil causes will await the ordinary tribunals. Causes in violation of military pro - clamations will be tried by military court. 7. No publication, either by newspaper, pamphlet, hand bill or otherwise, reflecting in any way upon the United States or the state of Nebraska or their officers, or tending to influence the public mind against the United States or the State of Nebraska or their officers, and no article commenting in any way on the work or action of the mili - tary authorities will be permitted.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 219 8. All assemblages in the streets, either by day or night, are prohibited. 9. All persons found on the streets who appear to be habitually idle and without visible means of support, will be placed under arrest. 10. While it is the desire of the authorities to exercise the powers of martial law mildly, it must not be supposed that they will not In vigorously and firmly enforced as occasion arises. By Command of LT. COL. ROBERT G. DOUGLAS. CAPT. VIRGIL J. HAGGART. Adjutant Four Mile Precinct, Military District STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN January 28, 1922. General Orders, No. 4 1. Martial Law having been proclaimed for Nebraska City and Four Mile Precinct, the following named officers and organizations of the Nebraska National Guard will proceed from their respective stations to Nebraska City to enforce the orders of the Commander-in-Chief : Worn: Osceola, Neb. — Lt. Col. Robert G. Douglas. 134th Inf.. com - manding. Lincoln, Neb. — Major Paul R. Halligan, Capt. Marcus L. Poteet, 1st Lt. Harry K. Grainger, 12 enlisted men Hq. Co., 3rd Bn., Company I, 134th Inf., and 3 officers and 20 enlisted men Hosp. Co., No. 130. Omaha, Neb. — Capts. Virgil J. Haggart and Thomas Q. Thornton, 134th Inf. Hastings, Neb. — Company G. 134th Infantry. Seward, Neb. — Company M, 134th Infantry. Auburn, Neb. — Company A, 134th Infantry. Falls City, Neb. — Company B, 134th Infantry. 2. Men will be in heavy marching order and overcoats. Cots, bed sacks, all available blankets, ammunition and organization equip - ment except '.eavy tentage will be taken. 3. Precautions will be taken by unit Commanders concerned for the proper safe-guarding of armories and property left at their home nations. 4. The conduct and appearance of the members of the command

220 REPORT OP THE ADJUTANT GENERAL and their attitude toward persons with whom they come in contact is if extreme importance. Extreme care must be used to show no favors lo either side of a controversy but duty must be performed firmly and pnnrteouBly. 5. The t'avel directed is necessary in the public service. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN, (Seal) Assistant Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN January 28, 1922. Special Orders, No. 21% 1. Major John A. Lawler, Judge Advocate General's Department, will proceed to Nebraska City, Nebraska, January 29, 1922, and re - port of the Commanding Officer, Nebraska National Guard, at that station for duty. 2. Colonel Amos Thomas will proceed to Nebraska City, January 30, 1922, and assume command of Nebraska National Guard troops on duty at that station upon his arrival. - 3. Lt. Col. Robert G. Douglas, on showing that he iis a member of the Legislature and that the Legislature is now in special session and considering questions of vital importance to the State, is hereby relieved from duty January 30, 1922. to return to his work in the Legislature. 4. 1st Sgt. Archie Morris, Regtl. Hq. Co., 134th Inf., and Master Sgt. Thomas A. Clarke, Regtl. Hq. Co., will proceed at once to Ne - braska City, Nebraska, and report to the Commanding Officer of troops at that station for duty immediately upon their arrival. 5. A detachment of seven men, Q. M. C, State Staff Corps and Departments, (to be designated by their Commanding Officer) will report to the Adjutant Genreal's Office forthwith, for the purpose of driving necessary trucks to Nebraska City. Upon arrival at Nebraska City, they will report to Capt. M. L. Poteet, Supply Officer, for duty. 6. Three Master Sergeants, Service Co.. 134th Inf., will proceed to Nebraska City, Nebraska, January 29, 1922, and report to Capt. M. L.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 221 Poteet, Supply Officer, 134th Infantry, for duty upon arrival. 7. Men will be in heavy marching order and overcoats. CoU, bed sacks, all available blankets, ammunition and organization equipment except heavy tentage will be taken. 8. The travel directed is necessary in the public senrice. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul. The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL HEADQUARTERS, MILITARY DISTRICT OP NEBRASKA CITY, NEBRASKA January 30, 1922 All persons found in Military Uniform In Four Mile Precinct, Otoe County, Nebraska, now under Military Authority, said persons not being under orders to report for Military Duty, will be immediately placed under arrest. In case of a fire alarm being suonded in the district at any time the flre department will function as usual and no assembly of citizens will be permitted. Order R. C. DOUGLAS. Lt. Col 134th Inf., S N G., Commanding. CAPT. VIRGIL J. HAGGERT, Adjutant. PROCLAMATION Whereas, Four Mile Precinct, in Otoe County, Nebraska, including the City of Nebraska City, Nebraska, and all of its subdivisions, has been declared and ordered by me, under and "object to martial law. and Whereas. The National Guard of the State of Nebraska has been ordered to, and has assumed charge and control of said District, and Whereas, a state of lawlessness, violence and disorder still exists and continues in said district now under martial law, and Whereas, There have been infractions and violations of the laws of the State of Nebraska, and of the rules and regulations prescribed for said district, now under martial law, now Therefore, I, Samuel R. McKelvie, Governor of the State of Nebraska, Vy virtue of my office, and of the authority vested in me by the Con-

222 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL stitution and Laws of the State of Nebraska, do hereby order, author - ize and empower the Commanding Officer of said district of Four Mile Precinct, including the City of Nebraska City and all of its subdivisions, now under and subject to martial law to create and appoint a Military Commission, or Provost Court, or both, to take cognizance and juris - diction of offenses against the public peace, and of violations of mili - tary rules and regulations, now in force, and as may be hereafter pro - mulgated, for the preservation of law and order, and the public safety in said district; and also, to take cognizance and jurisdiction of such violations of the civil law and the ordinances in force in said district as the Commanding Officer in his discretion may prescribe, as necessary for the public safety and the restoration of law and order in said district; and such Commission and Provost Court shall have full power and authority to issue all necessary process for the conduct of its proceedings, with like powers to compel the attendances of witnesses therein, as are exercised by the civil courts of the State of Nebraska. Given under my hand and the Great Seal of the State of Nebrask", this 30th day of Jan - uary, A D. 1922. SAMUEL R. McKELVIE, A TTEST . Governor of Nebraska Secretary of State. W. L. GASTON, Deputy Secretary of State. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN February 3, 1922. Special Orders No. 24% I. Lt. Col. Robert G. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERA1 223 130, February 8 and 9, 192 J Upon completion of this work he will return to his home station. 5. The travel directed is necessary in the public service. BY OltDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General. Nebraska. OFFICIAL: I'ROTIiAMATIOPr Whereas, The precinct of Four Mile, including the City of Nebraska City and all of its sub-divisions, in Otoe County, Nebraska, has been, heretofore, by me. declared and ordered under and subject to martial law, and Whereas, The National Guard of the State of Nebraska has been dispatched to, and has assumed charge and control of said District, and Whereas, The violence and disorder, heretofore prevalent and exist - ing in said District, has been suppressed and put down and does not now continue and exist, and Whereas. It appears that there is now no furthw need or necessity for maintaining longer a state of martial law in said district or for retaining in said district, the National Guard of the State of Nebraska, now Therefore, I, Samuel R. McKelvie, Governor of the State of Nebraska, by virtue of my office, and by virtue of the powers vested in me by the constitution and the laws of the State of Nebraska, do hereby announce, proclaim, declare and order that martial law shall cease to exist and shall terminate in said Military District of Four Mile Precinct, including the city of Nebraska City, and all of its sub-divisions, in Otoe county, Nebraska, upon the 16th day of February, A. D., 1922, at 10 o'clock A. M., and that after said time said district shall not be subject to or under martial law and that the Military Commission, created in and for said Military District, by the Commanding Officer thereof, upon the authority and order of proclamation heretofore issued by me, shall likewise cease to exist and function at said time, if not so ordered prior thereto, by the Commanding Officer of said Military District, but that the sentences imposed by said Military Commission upon persons duly brought before, tried, convicted and sentenced by said Military Commission shall remain, as approved by me, or as modified and approved by me, in full force and effect until the ex - piration thereof, and the Sheriff of Otoe County, Nebraska, Is hereby ordered to retain such persons in his custody until the expiration of said sentences; and I hereby call upon all civil authorities, in and

224 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL for Otoe county, Nebraska, and Nebraska City, Nebraska, whose duties may have been temporarily and partially suspended or in any manner interferred with or effected by the existence of martial law in said Military District, and upon all other civil officers in and for said county and said city, to assume and conscientiously perform the full duties of their respective offices and to faithfully execute the laws of the State of Nebraska. Glven under my hand and the Great Seal of the State of Nebraska, this 15th day of Feb- of Nebraska, this 15th day of Feb- ruary, A. D., 1922. SAjHUEL R. McKELVIE, ATTEST: D. M.
