I. Riot Gun, Corp. Snyder, Co. G Pistol, Lt. Runyan, Co. B. Bayonet. Pvt. Sherman, Co. G. The attached copies, together with the original copies of the charge sheets usr>d by the Military Commission, and the Intelligence Section, give in full detail a record of the administration for the entire period of martial law. The morale and conduct of the troops during this period was beyond reproach and brought credit to the Nebraska National Guard. Order was restored without a single casualty or accident. The health of the entire command was almost perfect, and the rations were beyond criticism. There was practically no interference with the civil ad - ministration, and the functioning of the civil courts was not suspended by the Military authorities. The activities of the Intelligence Section and the Military Commission were energetic, but always conducted with order, regularity, impartiality and dignity, as attested by the fact that in a habeas corpus proceeding instituted In the TTntyed States District Court for the District of Nebraska, the proceedings and sen - tences of the Military Commission were in all things affirmed by the Court. I "i"" 1 Respectfully submitted AMOS THOMAS, Colonel 134th Inf., N. N. G. Commanding Military Zone.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 242 Hugh Seymour and Ernest Watson having appealed from the finding of the military commission to the United States District Court in and for the District of Nebraska, Lincoln Division, the following memoran - dum opinion of the Court is published for the information of all concerned: MEMORANDUM OPINION IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE DISTRICT OF NEBRASKA, LINCOLN DIVISION. United States on relation of Hugh Seymour, Plaintiff vs. Edward H. Fischer, Sheriff, et al, Defendants. No. 374 Law. United States, on relation of Ernest Watson, Plaintiff vs. Edward H. Fischer, Sheriff, et al, Defendants. No. 374 Law. Munger, D. J. These are applications for writs of habeas corpus by two persons who have been committed to a term of imprisonment in a county jail of this state. The facts leading up to the imprisonment are as fol - lows: The go\ernor of the state had issued a proclamation declaring the existence at Nebraska City of a state of lawlessness and disorder beyond the control of the civil authorities and that the local officers had applied for military assistance to be placed in control of that territory for the restoration and maintenance of law and order. The proclamation therefore declared the territory to be subject to martial law and ordered the national guard of the state to occupy the terri - tory for the purpose of restoring law and order. After the troops were in possession of the territory, the governor authorized the appointment of military commissions to try offenses against the public peace and violations of any military rules and regulations. Each of the petitioners was charged with violation of some of these regulations, one, in retaining in his possession arms, equipment and munitions of war, and the other in keeping openaprohibited place of business, and each was found guilty and sentenced, and the commit - ments are in pursuance of these sentences. The petitioners were not employed in the military service and were citiz ens of Nebraska City. Th state courts at Nebraska City were open during all the time of mili - tary occupation. After the petitioners had served a portion of their sentences, the governor issued a proclamation reciting that violence and disorder had ceased at Nebraska City and he therefore terminated martial law and withdrew the troops. The chief claim of the petitioners is that their continued imprison - ment violates the due process of law guaranteed to them by the Four - teenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, (1) be - cause martial law did not exist at the time of their alleged offenses;

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 243 (2) because the military commission had no power to try them, and (3) because sentence by the commission could not outlast the period of military occupancy. Due process of law depends upon circumstances and varies with the sub ect matter and the necessities of the situation, and imprison - ment of citizens by the military commander may be lawful in some cases, Moyer v. Peabody, 212 U. S. 78. Art. 4, Sec. 14, of the Ne - braska constitution, makes the governor commander of the military forces of the slate and authorizes hi nito call out the militia to execute the laws and suppress insurrection. Sec. 3904 of the Compiledl Stat - utes of Nebraska (1913) authorizes the governor as commander-in-chief of the militia to employ it in the defense or relief of the state or any part of its inhabitants or territories and gives him all the powers neces - sary to carry into effect the provisions of that chapter of the statutes. Sec. 3913 of the same chapter provides that the militia may be called into service in time of war, invasion, riot, rebellion, insurrection, or reasonable apprehension thereof, and Sec. 3916 authorizes the gov - ernor to proclaim any portion of the state in a state of insurrection whon in his judgment the maintenance of law and order will be pro - moted thereby, and the militia are employed to aid the civil authority. Under such powers the governor may make the ordinary use of soldiers to suppress insurrection and his declaration of the existence of a state of insurrection is conclusive. Moyer v. Peabody, 212 U. S. 1; United States v. Wolters, 268 85 Pac. 190; State v. Brown, 71 78; Luther v. Borden et al, 7 How Fed. 60; In re Moyer. 35 Colo. 159 W. Va., 519, 77 S. E. 243; Ex Parto McDonald, 49 Mont. 454, 143 Pac. 947 Was the proclamation of the governor the declaration of a state of insurrection, or were the military forces called into service merely as aids to the civil officers for the purpose of assisting them in enforcing the laws? The proclamations do not use the word "insurrection," but the condition described of lawlessness and disorder beyond the control of the civil authorities and the declaration of martial law, are equivalent to a declaration of the existence of that organized resistance to authority known as insurrection, In re Charge to Grand Jury, 62 Fed. 828; Alleghany County v. Gibson, 90 Pa. 397. When a state of war or insurrection exists and the governor has legally called into action the military forces of the state, the will of the commander becomes the controlling authority in the occupied ter - ritory so far as he chooses to exert it, subject to the laws and usages of war. New Orleans v Steamship Company, 20 Wall. 387; United States v. Diekelman, 92 U. S. 520; Luther v Borden, et al, 7 How. 1; United States v McDonald, 265 Fed. 754; In re Egan, 5 Blatchf. 319, Fed. Cas. 4303; Commonwealth v. Shortall, 206 Pa. 165, 55 Atl. 952;

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 244 40 Cyc. 383, 390. As said by the Supreme Court of the United States in the case of Moyer v. Peabody, 212 U. S. 73, of the powers vested in the governor to suppress insurrection: "That means that he shall make the ordinary use of the soldiers to that end; that he may kill persons who resist, and, of course, that he may use the milder measure of seizing the bodies of those whom he considers to stand in the way of restoring peace. Such arrests are not necessarily for pun - ishment, but are by way of precaution to prevent the exercise of hostile power." Does the military power in the occupied territory which is de - clared under martial law extend to the trial and punishment of of - fenders against regulations made by the military commander? Some cases are cited in support of the proposition that the military forces can do no more than to arrest and detain offenders against the laws of the state until they can be delivered to the civil authorities for trial, upon the restoration of peace and order. (Franks v. Smith, 142 Ky. 232, 134, S. W. 484; Ex Parte McDonald, 49 Mont, 454, 143 Pac. 947). No doubt the commander may avail himself of the courts as a means of trial, but he may also institute tribunals during the emergency to deal with offenders in the district. The Grapeshot, 9 Wall, 129; New Orleans v. Steamship Co., 20 Wai. 387; United States v. Wolters, 268 Fed. 69; Winthrop on Mil. Law (2nd Ed.) 1295, 1301; Davis on Mil. Law 308; State v. Brown, 71 W. Va., 519, 77 S. E. 243; Ex Parte Jones, 71 W. Va. 567, 77 S. E. 1029. This is especially true of offenses against the military regulations, such as these petitioners committed, acts which are not offenses against the laws of the state. In cases of military occupancy during war or insurrection, the pass - ing of the military lines by persons without permission, the possession of arms and ammunition, the sale of intoxicating liquors, may cause the commander th eloss of a battle and yet these acts may not offend against the local laws. The usage in time of war has been to make regulations covering offenses in violation of the laws of war or of military discipline. Winthrop on Mil. Law (2nd Ed.) 1310, 1311. Can the sentence of imprisonment by such military tribunal be continued after peace is declared? This question has not been the subject of many reported decisions. The power to punish serious of - fenses by imposition of the death penalty is well understood and the lesser punishment of imprisonment for life has been sustained. Ex Parte Oritz, 100 Fed. 955. It is stated that during the civil war such military commissions acting under the authority of the United States held trials and entered judgment in more than two thousand cases. Winthrop Mil. Law (2nd Ed.) 1302, and that sentences of imprisonment for terms of years and for life were imposed (id 1313). See also Davis on Mil. Law 313. In cases of serious offenses, it is

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 245 not doubted that the sentence of imprisonment may continue during the war or insurrection. If the punishment is inflicted but a few days before the establishment of peace, it would seem absurd that sen - tences, otherwise just, should at once expire. While the necessity for crushing of further resistance may have passed, the reason for continuance of sentences therefore given has not ceased. The power of the military commander to make a lease of enemy city property extending beyond the termination of the war was sustained in New Orleans v Steamship Company, 30 Wall. 387. The conclusion is, that assuming the acts of the military court to have been done in accord - ance with the laws of the state, there is nothing in the exertion of this power which contravenes the right of due process of law guar - anteed by the Constitution of the United States. The rule on the defendants to show cause why the writ of habeas corpus should not be issued will be discharged. MEMORANDUM ON TRIAL OF CIVILIANS BY MILITARY COMMISSIONS From the Experience of Nebraska National Guard in Military Occupation of Four Mile Precinct, Including City of Nebraska City, In Otoe County. Nebraska. From Jan. 28. 1922 to Feb. 15, 1922, Nebraska City, Nebr., April 5. 1922. From: E.irl M. CUne, Major, 134th Inf., N. N. G. To: Whom It May Concern (Care Adjutant General of Nebraska): Subject: Memorandum on Trial ot Civilians by Military Commissions. Introductory Note. For the benefit of officials who may be hereafter charged with the duty of the maintenance of Martial Law within any prescribed District of tha State of Nebraska, and thereunder the trial of civilians by military com - r.iipsions, and subsequently the defense of the acts of such military com - missions, I note herewith a few matters relative to the experience of the Nebraska National Guard in sucl' matters, in the occupation of Four Mile Precinct, .ncluding the City of Nebraska City, all in Otoe County, Ne - braska, from January 28 to February 15, 1922. Declaration of Martial Law. In view of the litigation which subsequently took place regarding the validity of the proclamation of the Governor, creating Martial Law, in

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 246 the above described District, it seems to me that any subsequent proc - lamation of a Governor of Nebraska declaring Martial Law should be dif - ferent In some respects than the proclamation of the Governor of Ne - braska, dated January 28, 1922. This proclamation describes a condition oi insurrsctior; v. itliout actually denominating it as such. The proclama - tion declares Martial Law unequivocally, but it seems to me that if this occasion ever arises again, that the proclamation of January 28, 1922, should bo fo'lowod in this respect, and that also the proclamation shoul-J incorporate the evact words of the constitution and the Revised Statutes of Nebraska in the proclamation itself. By that I mean, the words "in - surrection, riot, etc., as used ind the constitution and statutes should be incorporated in the proclamation. Reference ia made in this matter to Article 4 Sectior. '4 of the Constitution of Nebraska, and Sections 3904. 3913, 3916, Rfeviset- Statutes of Nebraska, 1913. Except lor this point, the proclamation ot January 28, 1922, is considered sufficient. It was deter mined sufficient by Federal District Jundge Munger in the cases of the I'nited States of America ex rel Watson vs. Fischer, et al, and the United States of America ex rel Seymour vs. Fischer, et al, but I believe, tha* foilowlog the constitution and statutes, as above suggested, will eliminate in any mture proclamations any danger of the proclamation being de - clared insufficient. Proclamation of Military Commander. Martia! Law in a Military District is the will ol the Military Commander in that District. The proclamation ot Lieut. Col. Douglas, as Military Commander of Four Mile Precinct, dated January 28, 1922, is no doubt legally sufficient, on all matters covered therein. It is suggested, how - ever, that paragraph 6, relating to the countinuance of civil Courts bo c'ir.iiraud iroin publication, although such Courts continue to function as usual. Martial Law o! the character invoked at Nebraska City is an a'.soiu;- rora or Martial Law. A military District is created. The civil Courts do not function, except where permitted by the Military Com - mander. The civil Courts are not open, to take jurisdiction of cases, ot v.:-.ich the Military Commander wishes to take cognizance. Paragraph 6 o : ' th" proclamation ol' Lieut. Coi. Douglas, permits the raising in any - subsequent legal proceedings of the question of whether the civil Courts were actually closed. It seems to me that paragraph 6 should eithor be <>: litt d or that a rtat^ment should be made to the effect that the civil Courts are closed as to all cases which th.? military commander may, ir. exercise of his powers, determine properly within his jurisdiction for th.> purposes of the military occupation. It is p.lso suggested that the validity of any proclamation depends upon its publication to interested parties, and that hereafter publication be

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 247 proved by affidavits of newspapers publishing proclamations, and by affidavits 01 parties distributng proclamatons, such as that of Lieut. Col. Douglas, and that these affidavits be kept in the proper military files. To illustrate what I mean in this regard: If the litigation, growing out of the Nebraska City cases, had been carried to a higher Court, and it had become necessary to prove publication of the proclamation of Lieut. Col. Douglas, publication of the same in the two Nebraska City news - papers could, of course, be proved, but distribution of the proclamation by the persons actually performing the act would now, after this lapse of time, be more difficult, and no doubt, later on, practically impossible. Governor's Proclamation Creating Military Commission. The effect of Judge Monger's Decision in the Watson and Seymour cases, and his opinion as expressed during those trials, might indicate that the proclamation of the Governor, dated January 30, 1923, was un - necessary because if martial law were legally established, the inherent right to try persons violating the rules and regulations would go with such establishment of martial law. However, the proclamation of the Governor, dated January 30, 1922, leaves no question on this point, and also leaves no question on the point of the right of the Military Cor mander to take cognizance of infractions of the laws of the State of We - braska, necessary for the purpose for which military occupation is main - tained. This proclamation is considered sufficient and may, I believe, be safely followed in all respects. Order Creating the Court. The special order of Colonel Thomas, No. 14, dated February 2, 1922. is a necessary part of the procedure creating a military commission for the trial of civilians. Paragraph 1 is considered sufficient in all respects, as is also paragraph 2. In connoot'on with paragraph 2, it may be stated that my invest igntion of military commissions, in connection with the Seymour and Watson cases in the Federal Court, convinced me that military commissions for the trial of civilians should never be composed of less than three members. Winthrop on military law states this to be I he universal custom. For this reason, it seems to me that paragraph 3 is a bad paragraph, and that the three members of the commission should !>p present when trial is had, or if it is desired, to allow cases to proceed to trial with only a majority ol the commission present, that the com - mission should be composed of at least five members. Attention is again directed to the fact that the commission appainted in special order No. 14, was composed entirely of men admitted to practice law in Nebraska, and that this fact gave that commission standing and prestige generally, and made it easier to defend the findings of such commission. The Charge Sheet. Th^ charge sheets as used in the Nebraska City cases are considered

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 248 sufficient in all respects. However, it is to be emphasized that too much haste was shown in the preparation of the same. By that is meant, the filing in of the information in the blanks. Numerous errors are to be round in this respect. The charge sheets should be very carefully scrutinized by an officer of legal training before the same are served, to eliminate any of the errors, now found on the charge sheets, in the Nebraska City cases. Attention is also called to the fact that it is very vital for these charge sheets to show service of the same upon counsel for the accused, if he has one, and this also illustrates the necessity of having it show frequently In the record that the accused had counsel. It is suggested that if another such occasion ever arises that the blank forms for charge sheets be printed, and not mimeographed, and it will thereby be easier to keep a correct and good appearing record oi the case. The endorsements on the charge sheets are considered satisfactory and sufficient. Military commissions being military Courts, and endorsements should follow as nearly as possible the procedure of Courts Martial. At - tention Is particularly directed, however, to the endorsement of the Gov - ernor on each of the charge sheets, with the view that an Improvement may be made in this respect. As these endorsements now read, they begin as follows: "Reviewed, February 14, 1922." It will be recalled by officers connected with the occupation at Nebraska City, that this re - view by the Governor, or appeal to the Governor, was had at the request ol some of the several defendants. It is suggested that where this is the case that after the word "reviewed," that these words be added "Raviewed by the Governor of Nebraska, on appeal and request of the defendant , February 14, 1922." Not all of the Nebraska City defendants appealed, and of course, in such cases, such insertion could not be made, but in cases where such appeal was perfected at tho request of such defendant, such insertion is considered advisable for ihe following reason: Such appeal would show, in a measure, submis - sion to and acknowledgement of the jurisdiction of the Court, and of the Governor, as proper reviewing officer of the judgment of the Court. This particular point did not come up in the Seymour and Watson cases, but xjc considered raising it, had the cases been appealed, and it seems to me that R is a point worth considering, and desirable to make the record absolutely clear upon it. Attention Is also directed to the fact that the endorsements of he Governor show appearances, of counsel, this being for the purpose of showing that there was an actual hearing by the Governor, and that his approval was not merely a perfunctory or formal matter. Proclamation Terminating Martial Law. The proclamation of the Governor, dated February 15, 1922, terminal ing Martial Law, in the District created, is considered sufficient in all respects. Attention is invited to the fact that this proclamation by the

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 249 Governor as Commander in chief of he military forces of the State, commands the Sheriff to retain the prisoners in his hands until the ex - piration of iheir sentences. This also appears in the endorsement of the Governor on the charge sheet, which makes it serve as an order of com - mittment. As in the Nebraska City cases,, copy of the charge sheet with all endorsements thereon, of all prisoners, should be served upon the Sheriff, and his receipt taken, not only for the prisoners, but for the charge sheets, which are his orders of committment. Procedure in Writ of Habeas Corpus. II upon the termination of military occupation, application is made for writ of habeas corpus, as in the Seymour and Watson cases, proper re - turn to the application for the writ must be made. To draw such a return in the short time generally allowed, is a matter of some difficulty. Reference is therefore made to the answer and return of the respondents lo petition for a writ of habeas corpus in the cases in the District Court of the United States, for the District of Nebraska, Lincoln Division, en - titled United States of America ex rel Watson and ex rel Seymour vs. Fischer et al. These returns are considered sufficient. In the prepara - tion of such returns, it was considered necessary to set out a complete history of the military occupation, and of the particular prisoner for whom the writ is applied. Legal Propositions Involved in Habeas Corpus Action in the Watson and Seymour cases, it appeared that the following legal propositions were involved, and the following references were submitted by counsel for the respondents to Judge Munger in support of the legal - ity of the trial, conviction and the imprisonment of Watson and Seymour. These references are herewith noted for the benfit of any one who sub- sequently is obliged to meet the same issues as appeared in those cases. The opinion of Judge Munger is exhaustive and convincing and forms the basis for a valuable precedent in this kind of litigation. 1. The Governor has the power 1 to call out the military forces of the state to suppress riot, disorder and insurrection. The state possesses the inalienable right of protection and self preservation from the acts of lawless persons, banded together, when local civil authorities are inadequate to put them down. CONSTITUTION OF NEBRASKA. Act. IV. Sec. 14 REVISED STATUTES OF NEBRASKA, Sections 3904, 3913, 3916. LUTHER v. BORDEN, 12 L. ed. 581 GRIFFIN v. WILCOX, 21 Ind. 380 COMMONWEALTH v. SHORTALL, 206 Pa. 171, 98 Am. St. Rep. 759 MOYER v. PEABODY, 53 L. ed. 411 EX PARTE MOORE, 64 N. C. 602

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 250 EX PARTE KERR, 64 N. D. 816 IN RE BOYLE, 6 Idaho 609, 96 Am. St. Rep. 286 IN RE MAYER (Col.) 117 Am. St. Rep. 189 CHAPIN v FERRY, (Wash.) 15 L. R. A. 116 U. S. EX REL WATSON v. FISCHER— Fed. Ct. Lincoln Div. Nebr. 11. The establishment of military courts lor the trial of persons, sub - ject to martial law, is an inherent part of the right to declare martial law for martial law being declared in any part of a state as a result of disorder and insurrection, the war power of the state in the form or military rule prevails in the territory subject to the proclamation. STATE v. BROWN, 71 West Va. 519, An. Cases 1914 c-1. EX PARTE JONES (West Va.) 45 L. R. A. ns 1930 II WINTHROP MILITARY LAW, pp 1295-1321 DAVIS MILITARY LAW, p 307, et seq NOTES, 98 Am. St. Rep. 772 IN RE EGAN, 5 Blatch 319 EX PARTE MOORE, 64 N. C. 816 LUTHER v BORDEN, 12 L. ed. 581 III. A military court which has acquired jurisdiction of the person ac - cused, and of the offense charged, and has acted within the scope of its powers may impose a sentence which cannot be reviewed or set aside by the civil courts by habeas corpus, or otherwise, and such sentence will remain in full force and effect and be executed after the termination of martial law. IN RE ORITZ, 100 Fed. 955 JOHN v. SAYRE, 158 U. S. 109 WALES v. WHITNEY, 29 L. ed. 277 MC GORRY v. MURPHY, 17 Ann. Cases 444 EX PARTE VALLINDIGHAM, 17 L. ed. 589 STATE v. WALTERS 268 Fed. 69 U. S. EX REL WATSON v. FISCHER— Fed. Ct. Lincoln Div. Nebr. EARL M. CLINE, Major 134th Inf. N. N. G. and ot counsel for respondents United States of America ex rel Watson and Seymour vs. Fischer et al.
